snippet.textDisplay:
Great review, except for the one simple and crucial thing - essential design flaw of all Souls games... This game is no exception - due to mentioned design flaw, it is still made exclusively for those who have time to burn, desperately aiming to prove their fictional/virtual "worth" trough masochist mechanism of constant failure and bizarre time wasting "game" mechanics. It is like this - imagine killing all of your opponents on one level, investing time and effort and PROVING that you CAN defeat them, and than walking to a new boss, with completely unknown combat mechanics and characteristics, who kills you in 2 punches - only for "game" to return you all the way to the last checkpoint, reviving simply ALL of your enemies (same ones you spend so much time defeating - a challenge you already won and time you already spent) and destroying all your progress points/upgrade value points - souls. There is simply no logical mechanism in the world to justify this saving structure and process - it is simply the case of making something artificially hard and challenging - which is cheap manipulation, a lacking design - nothing more.

And yeah - sorry to burst some bubbles, but whole "git gud" mantra is really nothing more than great indicator of ones limited intellectual capabilities and severe incapability to understand that justifying an OBVIOUS design flaw via providing effort and "proving" that you actually CAN surpass it - means nothing more than that you are willing to invest/throw your time (and effort) in flawed-designed artificial challenges, instead of meaningful ones. Poor reasoning it is. :)

snippet.textDisplay:
Dark Souls is like a game of life.
You got kicked out from your home and about to face the world for the first time.
No direction on where to go, no money and a very few friends.
It's a damn cruel world but you bravely fight through it, only to fail and start from the beginning over and over again.
You become unhappy and frustrated.
Then you asked yourself, is it worth my suffering?  
With a little strength you have left, you get yourself up. What's more to lose anyway?
So you continue but you are now wiser than before.
Everyday is like a battlefield and there's no easy road.
Countless of failures but you keep your spirit high.
Until one day you have completed your journey. 
Only to realized that all the hardship you have experienced made you into a warrior.
And that the true happiness is not by completing the game itself but by overcoming all the adversities you have encountered in your journey.

snippet.textDisplay: they say area's are rehashed from old games but that's the point here. the world cycle has come to an end and there is no one that has linked the flame and that is why old lords of cinder's are being seeked to save the dying world. The undeads have lost even the slightest flame in them and have turned to ashen one's. in the end a mash up of all worlds of previous era is where the final battle in the kiln of the first flame begins as the soul of cinder guards his flame to prevent his world from dying and we are left with the fate of the world in our hand, are we to accept change or leave it the way it is for one day there is bound to be someone who will reignite the flame and the cycle will start again.

Glad I only bought it on sale.

snippet.textDisplay: There is a STEEP learning curve with DS3 that I was just not ready for 2 years ago. Only after about a year of hacking my way through the first few areas did I get skilled enough to consider myself a capable player. I am now by no means a skilled DS3 player, but I can hold my own against bosses and invaders. Be warned that the AI in this game is aggressive and powerful like nothing you've ever seen before, matched only by Bloodborne. Bosses and even regular enemies will not give you much breathing room; you'll just have to time those rolls and yes, git gud.
snippet.textOriginal: There is a STEEP learning curve with DS3 that I was just not ready for 2 years ago. Be warned that the AI in this game is aggressive and powerful like nothing you've ever seen before, matched only by Bloodborne. snippet.textDisplay:
You hated on some of the bosses, but honestly if you took a 100% new player with no prior info on the game and threw him into Dark Souls 3 it provided an amazing challenge. Even those bosses that were basically 4 hits like "oh shiny bracelet" or the yhorm tribute with the sword at his throne. And if you were a veteran who wanted that epic boss fight you had the option to take the long road, Yhorm and Wolnir are actually really hard to kill just beating on them instead of taking that strategic ez way out. 

Overall the best game I've ever played RPG wise, and im pretty picky. Frame rates dropping were annoying tho, so fair grade. But for the total experience it provided me, i'd have to give it a 11/10. Wish more games were like this one.
snippet.textOriginal:

And if you were a veteran who wanted that epic boss fight you had the option to take the long road, Yhorm and Wolnir are actually really hard to kill just beating on them instead of taking that strategic ez way out. 

Overall the best game I've ever played RPG wise, and im pretty picky. Frame rates dropping were annoying tho, so fair grade. But for the total experience it provided me, i'd have to give it a 11/10. Wish more games were like this one.

snippet.textDisplay:
Dark Souls - Best PVE yet not that good PVP system
Dark Souls II - Not that good PVE yet best PVP
Dark Souls III - I can say that the PVE is not bad at all but the PVP? Alright, I am not hating DS3 but what From was thinking when they made everyone to be able to chug? That thing drags every fight to god knows how long if you somehow don't manage to one-shot someone otherwise they have 10000 estus flasks to just get back to full health, 5 times. I myself prefer DS2 for PVP and DS1 for PVE but that is my opinion, I think that DS3 is worth it 9/10 but barely.
snippet.textOriginal:
Dark Souls - Best PVE yet not that good PVP system
Dark Souls II - Not that good PVE yet best PVP
Dark Souls III - I can say that the PVE is not bad at all but the PVP? Alright, I am not hating DS3 but what From was thinking when they made everyone to be able to chug? That thing drags every fight to god knows how long if you somehow don't manage to one-shot someone otherwise they have 10000 estus flasks to just get back to full health, 5 times. I myself prefer DS2 for PVP and DS1 for PVE but that is my opinion, I think that DS3 is worth it 9/10 but barely.

snippet.textDisplay: I posted this below the dark souls 2 scholar of the first sin review but I kinda feel like posting it here also cus I bought the two games at the same and I also experienced the same problem with each."This a warning to all those living in a country like mine where there is frequent power outage or unsteady power supply, please don't buy this game forget it's rating forget all what every reviewer said cus what they never tell you is this game has a save system that is easily corrupted. I can't tell you how many times I have play this game only to have my save data corrupted when the lights goes out. It doesn't matter how far you've gone or how careful you are once the lights goes out while you're playing prepare to start all over again. This games was not made for us in 3rd world countries or if you prefer developing nation's".

snippet.textDisplay:
A play games ofr 35 years - c64, Amiga, PS1,2,3,4, PC. And Dark Souls is one of the most praised games in that history. I don't have time for RPGs, but ok, let's try this wonder.

A would cal it FROGER game from arcades and latter C64. I supposed to be a knight, but all point in combat is jumping around like a frog. This has exactly nothing to do with real combat. Maybe it's great game, but this frog like combat system is (not totally) lame.

And i hate the commands. After a few hours playing on PS4 a keep pushing square when i want to fight and then i drink all this drinks of beautiful colors in the middle of fights. WHY i can't customize buttons?

snippet.textDisplay:
Good and Bad about DS III :
1. Combat mechanics is not as good as DarkSouls II
2. Bland story, repetitive and boring. 
3. Bad facial animation  & Clumsy lipsync. (some npc dont have it)
4. Pc game control and camera issues (cant jump using keyboard)
5. UI design is bad and old. 
6. Great sound effects and music but  BAD and LAME voice acted.
7. Obsolete graphics and textures.
8. Bland Main Character and NPC : do they exist ? :D
9. No crash which is good.
10. Zero replay value (0), yeah zero.


If you like Shadow of Mordor , youre gonna love this game, but Mordor is wayyyy better in combat mechanics.

Final score : 5.5/10 (Average)

Reviewed with : i7 7700k 32gb // 2xGTX1080Ti @all ultra @4k

snippet.textDisplay: only recently bought this as I was playing something else, I've played DS2 so really wanted this too and I can say the frame rate dips are not there anymore, and this is playing on high with a lowly GTX 950 & AMD FX 6300, I'm just over 190 hours in doing 3 play throughs at a zone each and have got all 3 just past the boreal dancer so far. The game is beautiful, you will be leaving "Praise the sun" messages all over the place (and praise the moon ;) ) when you see new areas. With my crappy cheap PC even on high I get steady smooth frame rates of mostly 60 FPS dropping to no lower than 50 with no stutter. More games should;d be like this.

snippet.textDisplay: I've been a From Software fanboy since Demon's Souls and have been very annoyed by all of the unclear dead ends. I keep finding my self fighting through very tough enemies and will spend an hour clearing an area, like the Cathedral of The Deep, and spend more time trying to find a way to the next area, that does not exist. There's no sign that these places are dead ends and, to refer to the Cathedral again, these dead ends can be massive areas. I'm the type of person that will dump ungodly amounts of hours seeing how many ng+ I can beat and will create many new characters. This is the first From game I've not finished.

snippet.textDisplay:
I waited for the price drop, so I just got the game last week.  I admit, I didn't go into the game blindly.  But, I didn't go blind into DS2 or BB either.  DS2 and BB were still incredibly challenging, each for their own reasons.  I felt like I had no problem blowing through DS3.  If you've played any souls game, plus Bloodborne, than this game should feel easy... I guess.  DS taught patience.  BB taught first strike, R1 overload, and parry out of control.  DS3 is a nice balance of both.
On the topic of bosses, everyone complained that DS2 used too many humanoid bosses that had 2-3 or 4 strike sets.  Everyone said that was boring and bland.  I think the non-humanoid bosses of DS3 were incredibly cheesy and incredibly easy.  The humanoid bosses in DS3 were actually the most challenging to me (the ones that took multiple tries to defeat).
DS2 was a grind, especially SOFS, but I felt a great sense of accomplishment when I defeated a boss or cleared each DLC.  I felt equally as good as I progressed through BB.  Some areas and bosses gave me such an adrenaline rush that I would have to take a break after them to calm my nerves.
I never felt that once in DS3.  DS3 is very pretty, but I don't think I'll be putting 100s of hour into it like I have every other game in the series.
Some DS3 gripes- short cuts are pointless, NPC quest lines are uninteresting, frame rate, easy access to all bosses, felt very linear.
I give it 7.5 of 10, because I love the Soulsborne series and I rank it-
1- Bloodborne
2- DS1
3- DS2
4- DS3
5- DS (haven't actually played)
It's not ranked higher, because I'm not going to give it bonus points for being prettier than the prequels.

DS3 is a nice balance of both.
On the topic of bosses, everyone complained that DS2 used too many humanoid bosses that had 2-3 or 4 strike sets.  Everyone said that was boring and bland.  I think the non-humanoid bosses of DS3 were incredibly cheesy and incredibly easy.  The humanoid bosses in DS3 were actually the most challenging to me (the ones that took multiple tries to defeat).
DS2 was a grind, especially SOFS, but I felt a great sense of accomplishment when I defeated a boss or cleared each DLC.  I felt equally as good as I progressed through BB.  Some areas and bosses gave me such an adrenaline rush that I would have to take a break after them to calm my nerves.
I never felt that once in DS3.  DS3 is very pretty, but I don't think I'll be putting 100s of hour into it like I have every other game in the series.
Some DS3 gripes- short cuts are pointless, NPC quest lines are uninteresting, frame rate, easy access to all bosses, felt very linear.
I give it 7.5 of 10, because I love the Soulsborne series and I rank it-
1- Bloodborne
2- DS1
3- DS2
4- DS3
5- DS (haven't actually played)
It's not ranked higher, because I'm not going to give it bonus points for being prettier than the prequels.

snippet.textDisplay: This is my first game in the souls series and I'm amazed how hooked I got on it. After 72 hours of game time I finally finished the game (some boss fights took hours to learn, literally) and like a roller coaster ride, I'm ready to hop on it again, but I'm not sure if I wanna go NG+ or roll an alt. It seems that if you get your character high enough you can just dive headfirst into a different build as opposed to rolling alts via Diablo 3
snippet.textOriginal: This is my first game in the souls series and I'm amazed how hooked I got on it. After 72 hours of game time I finally finished the game (some boss fights took hours to learn, literally) and like a roller coaster ride, I'm ready to hop on it again, but I'm not sure if I wanna go NG+ or roll an alt. It seems that if you get your character high enough you can just dive headfirst into a different build as opposed to rolling alts via Diablo 3

snippet.textDisplay:
Tried it out and once again I do not like the Souls games, dying over and over again just isn't fun, I like a challenge but not if it means staring at a "You Died" screen half the time.

The thing about Dark Souls that I dislike is that the movement is slow paced, the enemies are also mostly artificial difficulty, they do stupid amounts of damage and even instakill you at full health, it ends up being completely boring because of this. Near unplayable for me.

Ill stick to games like Killing Floo mr 2, Rainbow Six Siege and League of Legends, they provide a challenge but aren't incredibly unfair.

snippet.textDisplay: Okay, calm down, 9.5/10 is way to high. Since it is the last of the trilogy and hopefully the last installment, I was hoping for more then the same game with new bosses and a couple more fighting techniques. If you can't find new ways to innovate then start a new game instead of rinse and repeat. I give it a 7/10 since it is indeed very enjoyable, but just not worth anywhere near $60.

snippet.textDisplay: I love this game. I was first introduced to the developer through Bloodborne, and this game is just as amazing as that. I've recently made it to the Dragon Barracks bonfire, and for the first time in the game, I am having major frame and clipping issues. I'm being hit through floors, dropping frames, and dying all of the time because of it. I love the game, but I wish they had maybe sacrificed some graphical ability for the sake of performance.

snippet.textDisplay:
I give this game a 7.5 myself. The fact that they pulled so much crap with online pvp is really irritating. when invading, you are prioritized for worlds where the host has summoned a phantom, and half the covenants do the same job with the same rewards.

Further putting invaders at a disadvantage and doing a half-assed job with the covenants really kills it myself. A 1.5 off from the pvp aspect, and 1.0 off from the framerate dips.

I don't mean to be rude Chloi, but I would have appreciated it if when you gave this review, you delved into Dark Souls III's online multiplayer - both co-op and PvP.
snippet.textOriginal:
I give this game a 7.5 myself. The fact that they pulled so much crap with online pvp is really irritating. when invading, you are prioritized for worlds where the host has summoned a phantom, and half the covenants do the same job with the same rewards.

Further putting invaders at a disadvantage and doing a half-assed job with the covenants really kills it myself. A 1.5 off from the pvp aspect, and 1.0 off from the framerate dips.

I don't mean to be rude Chloi, but I would have appreciated it if when you gave this review, you delved into Dark Souls III's online multiplayer - both co-op and PvP.

snippet.textDisplay: Well...I'm late to this series. snippet.textDisplay: As a newbie to the franchise I would give this game an 8.5, 9 max, it is damn fun and makes me want to play it again as soon as I get off of it. From what I've heard though about all the other souls games, though, it does seem to me like something is lacking. Not necessarily in game play, but in game design I feel like there are a ton of quirks with the lock-on and how some enemies will just go berserk on you out of nowhere when you've faced them a hundred times before and they act in a semi-routine way. Again though I am a newbie so don't crucify me if 8.5 is too low :D

snippet.textDisplay:
I summoned a mad phantom with the intention of dueling him, but instead 
he sat down and offered to toast with me. We continued on throughout 
Undead Settlement together despite my wariness of him and he helped me 
take out all the mobs in the surrounding area. After a while, I became 
accustomed to fighting alongside my newfound friend and started turning 
my back to him knowing full well that he would protect me to his last, 
dying breath.

We were a team. The best of friends, and nothing 
could stand in our way. He may not have been a Warrior of Sunlight, but 
Solaire's legacy thrived on within him. Jolly co-operation resumed until
 we neared the Curse-Rotted Greatwood...  And it was then that I decided
 to take yet another chance and summon a second Mound-Maker to see if we
 could rally him to our side.

The plan seemed successful at 
first. But it wasn't long before I noticed some suspicious patterns in 
the phantom's movement, and his interest in my backside became a 
significant concern. My anxiety was proven justified when the phantom 
took a swing at me with his greatsword and missed.

My loyal 
protector raised both his hand and his middle finger at the attacker, 
before charging forward with fury the likes of which none in Lothric had
 seen. He made it his personal duty to end the traitorous life of the 
one who would dare attempt to strike at me, and before long the violent 
fool was fleeing from our jolly wrath. He rushed up a ladder and leaped 
across rooftops before finally dropping a harmful distance to the 
ground, giving us an opening to attack. My companion launched himself 
from the rafters and his flowing cape waved majestically in the air as 
he readied his sword and plunged towards the infidel who would dare spit
 on the tenets of co-operation and sunlight.

The valiant 
protector lunged his sword deep through the attacker's back before he 
could escape, the weapon grinding through bone and flesh and rendering 
him a lifeless husk. I dropped down following this, and we waved and 
spun our capes at one another in excitement and victorious glee.

But
 this was the end of our time together. We gave each other one final 
wave before my friend's body started to fade away as he was whisked back
 to his own dimension. 

It hit me I'd never see him again.

snippet.textDisplay: I think dark souls is a game which shouldn't be played with help. There are bosses that can be killed easily, but knowing how to, learning how to, is the point of it. If you are using guides like many people do, a lot of the bosses become easy. One of the most common one is in dark souls 1 with the drake. If played through the first time, not too many people would know how to kill it the easy way (without using help). But you can also challenge it straight on and kill it there (Which probably most people tried to do and it is possible but difficult). Theres also patterns if you keep replaying it, where you can find tricks and exploits to beat the drake. I think this is one of the points of dark souls and which is why this is such a fun game for me

snippet.textDisplay: bwwaahhh ds3 was so easy what a let down. everything has so much potential but the consistency just isn't there! bosses are easy because they have too little hp and low dmg, enemies have bad pathing and the world consistency found in ds1 and bloodborne simply isn't back. ds3 suffers from the same problem as ds2. it just throws world's at you that look pretty but make absolutely no sense to be there. why is there an open sky above when you just went deep underground, why can walking through a tunnel change the time of day and environment entirely. it's just not consistent and it's so bothering. they really went with show over substance and it's just below fromsoft to do so.

snippet.textDisplay:
DARKSOULS REVIEW 


Overall, the community is easy going and the players are kind to one another. You will find yourself being helped throughout the game with powerful npc’s and fair mechanics. Other players will also be available to summon and will protect you from harm. This is a game for people who want to take it easy and enjoy themselves. If you are interested in hardcore game I would suggest you turn to a more complex game like Borderlands. 


With that being said, be sure to check out Dark Souls III if you enjoy games: 

that are easy to learn 
that don’t have steep learning curves 
that will tell you where to go 
that don’t screw you over with unfair 1-hit combos 
that have a story you don’t have to find out on your own

snippet.textDisplay:
I've never played a dark souls game before... So I want to ask carefully because I'm making a choice whether or not to buy this game.   
First of all, this game is not made to show off its visual effects like high-end graphics and textures in my opinion, so I'll skip that. so I tried to focus on the gameplay, and after I watched couple of others playing this series, I wondered if it's kind of repetitive, since it 'looked like' just dodging and pressing the attack button over and over. (and dying over and over, I think)
Sorry to people who got offended by this comment, but I'm not trying to fight or start a warzone here. As I said, I'm just asking if it is worth buying this game.

This is the first Souls game i've bought on release, i gota say i'm loving the quick connections for a change.
The weak & meak were weeded from the games long before i picked up the others.

I see a lot of the steam reviews giving the game negative due to things like lag. Well i just want to say it's not just PC users, the Xbox version has some pretty bad dips in the frames also.
I'm just saying i'd expect it to be improved with a patch in a week or so.

snippet.textDisplay: I´ve never tried a Souls game before, but I have been interested in this series for quite some time. I have some questions for you Souls veterans, and if you reply to me I will be ever so greatful! Is there alot RPG elements in this game? I´m no RPG guy, and I think I have only played like two RPGs in my whole gaming life. Is this as hard as everyone is saying? I dont mind ¨hard/difficult¨ games as long as its fair. What really got me interested in this series is the overworld, the athmosphere in general, the intense boss fights and etc.. You may say that I should try Bloodborne first, but I kinda spoiled the game for myself with most of the bosses and the final stage. I have no idea what the story is about in Bloodborne, but is it worth it when I have seen all of the bosses mostly?

snippet.textDisplay: 9.5? From what you were saying in your review (which was very well laid out and presented) I was expecting a 7 or 8. Why does IGN dole out such high scores to games all the time, the average should be 5, whereas I feel IGN's average is closer to 9. It just means that I can't take anything away from the score you give it, and why you had to introduce .5's in your final scores. There would be no need if you used the scale correctly. The only reason I can see for you doing so is so that you get your name on the box with a high score next to it, which is really not what journalism should be about. Other than that it was a comprehensive and well done review, keep up the good work.
snippet.textOriginal: 9.5? From what you were saying in your review (which was very well laid out and presented) I was expecting a 7 or 8. snippet.textDisplay:
I don't really agree with the score 9.5 / 10. 
DS3 haven't change since the first game, it still lack good story (or story at all) and overall point of playing. The battle system is indeed challenging, but I wouldn’t say that it has improved. More like adjust to current time and players. I don’t see any improvement in gameplay like in Witcher or Elders Scrolls, in which you can see massive features added and changes that was implemented in every new sequel. To tell you the truth Dark Souls 1,2 and Blood Born is basically the same game with some details changed. By the above I wouldn’t say even that Dark Souls series is an RPG, more likely Hack & Slash. In my opinion 6 / 10 is fair score for game that have no story and lack of update to engine. Considering DS3 “Game of the Year 2016” would be overstatement and big exaggeration. Of course if 2016 have no other candidates for this tittle. And if so, making DS3 game of the 2016 would be a massive downgrade in comparison to 2015.
snippet.textOriginal:
I don't really agree with the score 9.5 / 10. 
DS3 haven't change since the first game, it still lack good story (or story at all) and overall point of playing. The battle system is indeed challenging, but I wouldn’t say that it has improved. More like adjust to current time and players. I don’t see any improvement in gameplay like in Witcher or Elders Scrolls, in which you can see massive features added and changes that was implemented in every new sequel. To tell you the truth Dark Souls 1,2 and Blood Born is basically the same game with some details changed. By the above I wouldn’t say even that Dark Souls series is an RPG, more likely Hack & Slash. In my opinion 6 / 10 is fair score for game that have no story and lack of update to engine. Considering DS3 “Game of the Year 2016” would be overstatement and big exaggeration. Of course if 2016 have no other candidates for this tittle. And if so, making DS3 game of the 2016 would be a massive downgrade in comparison to 2015.

snippet.textDisplay:
I'll admit it, I'm a Souls fanboy.
That said, the 9.5 score has nothing to do with what I'm about to say:
IGN should give Chloi Rad a RAISE. This is the kind of review I USED to expect from IGN. The fact that she went SO in depth with describing how the weapons and combat worked impressed me immensely. The only thing that would have impressed me more would have been delving into magic/miracles.

Well done, Chloi. If IGN executive staff have half a mind, we'll be hearing from you A LOT MORE.
snippet.textOriginal:
I'll admit it, I'm a Souls fanboy.
That said, the 9.5 score has nothing to do with what I'm about to say:
IGN should give Chloi Rad a RAISE. This is the kind of review I USED to expect from IGN. The fact that she went SO in depth with describing how the weapons and combat worked impressed me immensely. The only thing that would have impressed me more would have been delving into magic/miracles.

Personally most disappointing things are
1. some weakpoint/ gimmick boss fight, really waste the design of these boss.And their HP is awwwwww too few.
2. Removed duel- wielding weapon stance (power stance) by adding duel weapon....nope :( 

other last disappointing things are
1.Boss weapons are pretty useless, buff is needed.
2. Need to balance the amount of FP use by melee and magic user.
3. invasion system, ganker is ok but need a tune in balancing players stat (it not working at all)

Lore is so far okay for me, BGM is awesome 10/10.
Hope we have a continuous fix and update for the game,afterall it is the LAST Souls game for us Q_Q. ( like adding more moveset and style for the last boss until he can truely use all the weapon form and magic in the whole series.)<-pls

snippet.textDisplay: Well miss Chloi, I gottta say this was a masterfully done review. Not only you provided us with much more feedback than Gamespot's reviewer, but you also managed to combine objective analysis with subjective opinion in an extremely satisfying and smooth way. The fact that you lowered the game's score based only on the factual objectivity, and not on the couple of negative opinions you had on certain elements ( while still making sure to warn us about them ) is a brilliant move in my book, and should be a new standard in the reviewing profession. GG gurl.

snippet.textDisplay: These kind of games are  just not fun!  You don't excel at them by becoming better at the core mechanics, instead you slog away trying to level up,  while trying to remember where all the monsters are, and hoping you come across a ring down a random corridor that will double your health!  They are games for masochists. It isn't hardcore to hate yourself!
